Articles.Content:
Interview on the live stream: http://rosetta.esa.int/

Landing gear on Philae has successfully deployed.

Edited November 12, 2014 by Sky_walker

"Comet landing already a disaster, say parking bores"

Men who claim to know about parking have been strongly critical of the techniques being used to place the Philae lander on a comet.

36-year-old Stephen Malley, who is following events online, said: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, no, no, no. They are using way too much thruster...

Full article:

http://www.thedailymash.co.uk/news/science-technology/comet-landing-already-a-disaster-say-parking-bores-2014111292689

https://soundcloud.com/esaops/a-singing-comet

Full article on this is here.

http://blogs.esa.int/rosetta/2014/11/11/the-singing-comet/

I'm starting to see internet congestion issues with the stream.

I hope there isn't a server crash once it gets close and more people are watching.
I'm hoping for two things. Firstly a safe landing and secondly that they don't find three naked space vampires when they land.

I hope there isn't a server crash once it gets close and more people are watching.

On can't rule out a crash; but the feed comes via akamai. They usually have the resources and bndwdth to handle a lot of users. So I think we wouldn't see a overload of the content-delivery Infrastructure.

Just hit F5 if you have problems with connection/routing/etc to the live feed. It works fine.

ESA Rosetta blog went down. Web servers can't cope with the traffic.

And they say people are uninterested in space...

I'm jealous of all you guys able to watch it, by the way. I even need to jump through hoops to be able to forum-post from work... video streams are right out. And even if I could make it work, the machine I'm on has no ability to output sound.

Edited November 12, 2014 by Streetwind

Just hit F5 if you have problems with connection/routing/etc to the live feed. It works fine.

It works fine for about 10-25 seconds, then bogs down again. Just like yesterday. Does anyone have the direct feed adress? I want to try to watch it directly from a media player, to see if that makes any difference. I can't seem to find the address though.

do anyone knows if there are any mods adding comets to ksp?

even better, this specific comet and rosetta + philae?

that would be awesome!

It works fine for about 10-25 seconds, then bogs down again. Just like yesterday. Does anyone have the direct feed adress? I want to try to watch it directly from a media player, to see if that makes any difference. I can't seem to find the address though.

You tried different browsers?

VPN connection to another server?

Live stream is here: http://new.livestream.com/esa/cometlanding

ps. for everyone else - if you'll scroll down you can see previous highlights.

pps. for me xkcd breaks more often than not :/

pps. for me xkcd breaks more often than not :/

Best to view here.

Edited November 12, 2014 by Kryten

Separation from Rosetta taken earlier.

Viewing the underside of the solar panel and main body of Rosetta.

Bright spot is the Sun.

Edited November 12, 2014 by Tommygun
Incredible picture of Rosetta, isn't it? If I recall correctly, that picture was taken 50 seconds after separation and totally autonomously. Go ESA!

You tried different browsers?

VPN connection to another server?

As stated before, a different browser combined with another version of Flash seems to have done the trick.

Live stream is here: http://new.livestream.com/esa/cometlanding

That's the webpage, not the URL of the stream itself. The latter is useful to view the stream directly in a media player, rather than through a browser. Just that address will not work.
Bye Philea, bon voyage, and keep in touch!
Just imagine, that picture is the first time in 10 years (!!!) the engineers saw her last.
Is anyone else physically excited here? I can imagine a bit how people watching the moon landing must have felt. My extremities can't seem to keep still and my stomach seems to be crawling.

Is anyone else physically excited here? I can imagine a bit how people watching the moon landing must have felt. My extremities can't seem to keep still and my stomach seems to be crawling.

I am glued to the webcast and it has been on since the separation 6 hours ago. So damn excited and scared about what is happening next... I hope it ends like the curiosity landing. I so want to see a pic of the surface, I might be in my mid thirties I feel like a little kid heh heh.

Edit: here comes the exicting bit landing any time from now. Most likely in 20 minutes!

Edited November 12, 2014 by merlinux

Are we there yet?

I might be in my mid thirties I feel like a little kid heh heh.

I am both happy and sad to say I am a little kid, no matter how old I grow

Are we there yet?
We won't know until confirmation of the landing (20min-30min from now). Although from my understanding the event is actually happening right now. Communication takes about 30min.

Is anyone else physically excited here? I can imagine a bit how people watching the moon landing must have felt. My extremities can't seem to keep still and my stomach seems to be crawling.

I'm getting there. I just connected to the live stream.
So Philea must have just landed (or not, but hopefully has!!). So tense! but they look pretty calm in mission control!
